Pre-requisites
BIOLOGY & ECOLOGY FIELD SKILLS 2022-23
HESA Cost Centres
Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
This module considers the ecology, identification and conservation of birds. It seeks to provide an evidence based understanding of bird conservation through studying bird ecology. Key to this is the ability to identify species and assess how key ecological concepts apply to this group. This course will teach students to integrate avian ecology with population and habitat management practices. It will illustrate the links between management and avian biology, habitat fragmentation, migration, and other ecological concepts. Throughout the module, emphasis is placed on the role of research methods in ornithology and how data gained are used to achieve maximally effective conservation and management. The module is aimed at students studying C100 Biological Science and C300 Zoology. The module will be of interest to students wishing to learn more about birds, including those who wish to pursue a career in ornithology or applied ecology.
Educational Aims
This field based module aims to provide experience in many current techniques and methods used to identify, monitor and manage birds in the UK.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module considers the ecology, identification and conservation of birds. It seeks to provide an evidence based understanding of bird conservation through studying bird ecology. Key to this is the ability to identify species and assess how key ecological concepts apply to this group. This course will teach students to integrate avian ecology with population and habitat management practices. It will illustrate the links between management and avian biology, habitat fragmentation, migration, and other ecological concepts. Throughout the module, emphasis is placed on the role of research methods in ornithology and how data gained are used to achieve maximally effective conservation and management. The module is aimed at students studying C100 Biological Science and C300 Zoology. The module will be of interest to students wishing to learn more about birds, including those who wish to pursue a career in ornithology or applied ecology.
Outline Syllabus
Week 1 Key anatomical features important in the identification of birds. This involves a trip to the Liverpool World Museum where students are introduced to the importance of museum collections, and undertake exercises utilising the collections to identify birds.
Weeks 2-5. Field trips. Students will undertake four field trips to local nature reserves that are owned by different conservation groups. These might vary year on year but are likely to include RSPB Leighton Moss/Burton Mere, WWT Martin Mere, CWT LNR, Risley Moss and WECG, Woolston Eyes. These sites provide a range of habitats, bird species and conservation issues including, reedbed, marsh, flooded woodland and lowland heath/bog and associated species. Students will experience real life examples of species conservation and habitat management. They will evaluate the approaches to species conservation and habitat management at each site as well as learning species identification and monitoring skills. Students will maintain a field diary of their visits.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: There is one introductory lecture to the field trip series. Each field trip will be preceding by a synchronous fieldwork preparation electure.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Museum Work
Description: This refers to the visit to the zoology collections at the World museum.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3 - Fieldwork
Description: This refers to site visits to various nature reserves in the North West
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Self-Directed Learning Description: Guided and self-directed reading, reflection on learning, formative assessments, preparation for summative assessments and private study.

Currently, we have permission to take students into the field but if the COVID situation worsens we will provide virtual fieldwork online. All fieldwork will adhere to the UoL social distancing guidelines and PPE will be provided.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
Assessment 1 will be an online open book exam. It will assess the students' abilities to identify birds based upon written descriptions, photographs, recordings of songs and calls. This assessment is worth 40% of the overall module mark.
Assessment 2 will be a Species Action Plan. Based upon the field notes and research students will complete a species action plan for a fictional species of bird at a named location. This is worth 60% of the overall module mark. There is a reassessment opportunity.
Assessment 1 anonymous
Assessment 2 cannot be completed anonymously because it involves continuous data collection, and some face to face interaction with tutors.
Health and Safety
The MO is a qualified 1st aider. No lone fieldwork will be allowed.
Admin
Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Notes
The rationale for the introduction of this module is in response to student feedback from the past year requesting that students have more opportunities to undertake fieldwork and staff feedback highlighting a skills deficit, amonst students, in organismal identification. There is also a perceived lack of conservation taught in year 2. Giving students more opportunities to complete authentic assessments, do enquiry based learning and work with potential employers reflects elements of the C2021 strategy.

 5 evaluate appropriate management and conservation approaches to answer a specific ornithological issue

BIOLOGY & ECOLOGY FIELD SKILLS 2022-23
HESA Cost Centres
Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
This module considers the ecology, identification and conservation of birds. It seeks to provide an evidence based understanding of bird conservation through studying bird ecology. Key to this is the ability to identify species and assess how key ecological concepts apply to this group. This course will teach students to integrate avian ecology with population and habitat management practices. It will illustrate the links between management and avian biology, habitat fragmentation, migration, and other ecological concepts. Throughout the module, emphasis is placed on the role of research methods in ornithology and how data gained are used to achieve maximally effective conservation and management. The module is aimed at students studying C100 Biological Science and C300 Zoology. The module will be of interest to students wishing to learn more about birds, including those who wish to pursue a career in ornithology or applied ecology.
Educational Aims
This field based module aims to provide experience in many current techniques and methods used to identify, monitor and manage birds in the UK.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module considers the ecology, identification and conservation of birds. It seeks to provide an evidence based understanding of bird conservation through studying bird ecology. Key to this is the ability to identify species and assess how key ecological concepts apply to this group. This course will teach students to integrate avian ecology with population and habitat management practices. It will illustrate the links between management and avian biology, habitat fragmentation, migration, and other ecological concepts. Throughout the module, emphasis is placed on the role of research methods in ornithology and how data gained are used to achieve maximally effective conservation and management. The module is aimed at students studying C100 Biological Science and C300 Zoology. The module will be of interest to students wishing to learn more about birds, including those who wish to pursue a career in ornithology or applied ecology.
Outline Syllabus
Week 1 Key anatomical features important in the identification of birds. This involves a trip to the Liverpool World Museum where students are introduced to the importance of museum collections, and undertake exercises utilising the collections to identify birds.
Weeks 2-5. Field trips. Students will undertake four field trips to local nature reserves that are owned by different conservation groups. These might vary year on year but are likely to include RSPB Leighton Moss/Burton Mere, WWT Martin Mere, CWT LNR, Risley Moss and WECG, Woolston Eyes. These sites provide a range of habitats, bird species and conservation issues including, reedbed, marsh, flooded woodland and lowland heath/bog and associated species. Students will experience real life examples of species conservation and habitat management. They will evaluate the approaches to species conservation and habitat management at each site as well as learning species identification and monitoring skills. Students will maintain a field diary of their visits.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: There is one introductory lecture to the field trip series. Each field trip will be preceding by a synchronous fieldwork preparation electure.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Museum Work
Description: This refers to the visit to the zoology collections at the World museum.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3 - Fieldwork
Description: This refers to site visits to various nature reserves in the North West
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Self-Directed Learning Description: Guided and self-directed reading, reflection on learning, formative assessments, preparation for summative assessments and private study.

Currently, we have permission to take students into the field but if the COVID situation worsens we will provide virtual fieldwork online. All fieldwork will adhere to the UoL social distancing guidelines and PPE will be provided.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
Assessment 1 will be an online open book exam. It will assess the students' abilities to identify birds based upon written descriptions, photographs, recordings of songs and calls. This assessment is worth 40% of the overall module mark.
Assessment 2 will be a Species Action Plan. Based upon the field notes and research students will complete a species action plan for a fictional species of bird at a named location. This is worth 60% of the overall module mark. There is a reassessment opportunity.
Assessment 1 anonymous
Assessment 2 cannot be completed anonymously because it involves continuous data collection, and some face to face interaction with tutors.
Health and Safety
The MO is a qualified 1st aider. No lone fieldwork will be allowed.
Admin
Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Notes
The rationale for the introduction of this module is in response to student feedback from the past year requesting that students have more opportunities to undertake fieldwork and staff feedback highlighting a skills deficit, amonst students, in organismal identification. There is also a perceived lack of conservation taught in year 2. Giving students more opportunities to complete authentic assessments, do enquiry based learning and work with potential employers reflects elements of the C2021 strategy.
